snippet: A stinging report by the Senate Intelligence Committee blames both American diplomats and spies for poor communication and lax security before the deadly 2012 episode in Libya.
abstract: Senate Intelligence Committee's stinging report concludes attack on Sept 11, 2012, that killed four Americans in Benghazi, Libya, could have been prevented; singles out State Dept for criticism for its failure to bolster security in response to intelligence warnings about growing security crisis around city; criticizes United States Ambassador J Christopher Stevens for his judgment and actions in weeks before his death.

byline.original: By MARK MAZZETTI, ERIC SCHMITT and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
byline.contributor: Mark Mazzetti and Eric Schmitt reported from Washington, and David D. Kirkpatrick from Cairo.

lead_paragraph: A stinging report by the Senate Intelligence Committee blames both American diplomats and spies for poor communication and lax security before the deadly 2012 episode in Libya.

headline.main: Benghazi Attack Called Avoidable in Senate Report
headline.print_headline: Benghazi Attack Called Avoidable in Senate Report
